steps.title: Thaw your turkey in the fridge if it’s frozen.
steps.content: Thaw your turkey in the fridge if it’s frozen. It takes about 24 hours to thaw for every 5 pounds (2.3 kg) of turkey. Check if the turkey is completely thawed by inserting a thermometer into the breast at a few different places. The temperature should be between 32 to 40 °F (0 to 4 °C). [1] X Research source For example, it will take about 3 days for a 15 lb (6.8 kg) turkey to thaw. [2] X Research source You can also thaw it more quickly in ice water. Put the wrapped turkey in a plastic bag and submerge it in a bucket of cold water. Change the cold water every 30 minutes. It will take about 30 minutes per 1 pound (0.45 kg). Don’t leave your turkey to thaw at room temperature.

steps.title: Place your turkey on a sheet tray or in the sink.
steps.content: Place your turkey on a sheet tray or in the sink. Don’t put the turkey in a roasting tray yet, because it will drip a lot of juices as you open it up that you don’t want to cook with. Instead, put the turkey on a sheet tray or in the sink. [3] X Research source Keep in mind that you will have to clean and sanitize whatever surface comes in contact with raw meat.

steps.title: Remove the wrapping from the turkey.
steps.content: Remove the wrapping from the turkey. Flip the turkey upside down, and make a slit in the wrapping with a knife. Peel open the wrapping around the turkey to totally remove it. Throw the wrapping directly in the trash since it had contact with raw meat. [4] X Research source It’s best to open the turkey packaging from the back, so that if you accidentally slit the skin you won’t cut into the breast meat. If the turkey legs are hooked together with a plastic piece, you can leave that on during roasting.

steps.title: Locate the body cavity between the back legs.
steps.content: Locate the body cavity between the back legs. The butcher will have cut a large hole between the legs, inside of which you can see the giblets and neck if they are there. The body cavity is fairly large and hard to miss. [5] X Research source If you don’t immediately see the package of giblets, it might be underneath the neck. If there isn’t a body cavity, you will have to gut your turkey, which is a more involved process than simply removing the giblets.

steps.title: Reach into the body cavity to pull out the giblets.
steps.content: Reach into the body cavity to pull out the giblets. Butchers will usually wrap the giblets in paper or plastic and store them in the front cavity of the turkey. Reach into the body cavity and remove the package. [6] X Research source Ready-to-cook whole poultry is required to be packaged with giblets in the US. If the giblets might be missing, the poultry processor has to mark the package “giblets may be missing.”

steps.title: Pull the neck out of the body cavity, if necessary.
steps.content: Pull the neck out of the body cavity, if necessary. Even if there are no giblets in the body cavity of your turkey, the neck might still be there. Butchers will either put it in the body cavity or the front cavity. The neck looks like a long rod. [7] X Research source You can use the turkey neck to make gravy, soup, or smoked turkey neck. [8] X Research source You can also just throw the turkey neck away.

steps.title: Check the front cavity for giblets as well.
steps.content: Check the front cavity for giblets as well. Sometimes, the butcher will store the package of giblets in the front cavity instead of the body cavity. Look at the top of your turkey, between the wings. There will be a hole where the neck once was. Pull open the hole so you can look inside. If there’s a package of giblets there, pull it out. [9] X Research source If the package claims there are giblets in the turkey, but you don’t see them, check again.

steps.title: Set aside the giblets for cooking or toss them.
steps.content: Set aside the giblets for cooking or toss them. You can use giblets in gravy, stock, or side dishes. Some people like to cook the turkey with the giblets directly underneath, to give a richer flavor to the gravy. However, if you don’t want to bother, you can just toss the giblets. [10] X Research source If you throw out the giblets, make sure to take out the trash within a few hours so the smell doesn’t get bad.

steps.title: Pat the turkey dry with paper towels.
steps.content: Pat the turkey dry with paper towels. Take a handful of paper towels, and pat dry the entire outside of the turkey. Turkeys roast much better when they are dry. Remember to throw out the paper towels immediately. [11] X Research source It’s better to pat rather than rub so that the paper towels don’t shred onto the turkey.

steps.title: Wash your hands and work surfaces with hot soapy water.
steps.content: Wash your hands and work surfaces with hot soapy water. Wash your hands with warm water and soap, scrubbing for at least 20 seconds before rinsing them with running water. Also, scrub your counters, utensils, cutting boards, sink, trays, and anything else that touched the raw turkey with warm soapy water. Do this is as soon as you’re done cleaning out the turkey, because bacteria from raw meat is dangerous. You can also sanitize the surfaces with bleach and water to be extra safe. Make a diluted mixture of bleach and water, with a ratio of 1 tablespoon (15 mL) bleach to 1 gallon (3.8 L) water. Let the bleach mixture sit on the counter for 2 minutes and then wipe it off.

steps.title: Cook your turkey
steps.content: Cook your turkey with your favorite method. You can roast , smoke , grill, or deep fry your turkey. You can get fancy with the spices or even wrap your turkey in bacon. [12] X Research source Don’t leave your turkey sitting around – if you’re not going to cook it immediately, put it back in the fridge.
